subject: Add QObject::isQuickItemType() for convenience

values.-1: I would prefer this is not merged as is
values.+1: Looks good to me, but someone else must approve

messages.message:
Patch Set 1:

(3 comments)

What's the use case for this?

Patch Set 1:

(1 comment)

I suppose isWidget and isWindow make as much sense as this one, but am also curious where you think it will make a big speedup?

Patch Set 1:

(1 comment)

I'll join the chorus of the use-case requester.

Patch Set 1:

Good idea! Perhaps this should include a specialization for qobject_cast?

Patch Set 1:

> Patch Set 1:
> 
> Good idea! Perhaps this should include a specialization for qobject_cast?

As the first one who unconditionally says that this is good, feel free to provide the use case for it, too ;-)

About qobject_cast, do you mean
template<>
inline qobject_cast<QQuickItem *>(QObject * obj) { /* logic */ }

in qquickitem.h like the variant in qwidget.h for widgets?

Patch Set 1:

Maybe it's for when you want to access properties through the metaobject without actually linking Qt Quick?

Patch Set 1:

> Patch Set 1:
> 
> Maybe it's for when you want to access properties through the metaobject without actually linking Qt Quick?

I look at this simply as a way to optimize qobject_cast; I haven’t tinkered in QtQuick a lot yet, but I think almost all bugs I tried to fix exposed me to code that qobject_cast’ed a QObject to a QQuickItem (focus handling, modality/popup handling I think). A specialized template that can use the bit like the QWidget specialization (IIRC) instead of walking the metaobject tree should save a few cycles.

Patch Set 2:

(4 comments)

> What's the use case for this?

In one of my project, I'm retrieving some information from Qt's GUI things, but I don't want to have a dependency for QtWidgets and QtDeclarative (because I only need these data to do some math calculations), so I'm using raw QObject pointers to retrieve these info through Qt's meta object system, something like obj->property("some property").toSomeType(), but QQuickItem's properties are not exactly the same with QWidget's properties, so I have to judge between them. And due to most Qt classes inherits from QObject, to make the code robust, I also have to judge whether the given QObject is inherited from QWidget/QQuickItem or not. We have isWindow/isWidget for this kind of scenarios so I wonder why we only lack the one for Qt Quick. I admit I can use obj->inherit("QQuickItem") to do the same thing, but it doesn't look very good if use this together with isWidget. That's the initial motivation of this commit. Although it's my personal use case, I expect it will become useful for others in the future if we have this function.

> I suppose isWidget and isWindow make as much sense as this one

Totally agree.

> but am also curious where you think it will make a big speedup?

Do you mean the "faster" mentioned in the documentation? The whole documentation is copy-pasted from isWidget, I only replaced "widget" with "QQuickItem". If isWidget is faster than inherit("QWidget"), then isQuickItem should be faster than inherit("QQuickItem") as well, because they are using the same tech.

Patch Set 2:

> Patch Set 2:
> 
> (4 comments)
> 
> > What's the use case for this?
> 
> In one of my project, I'm retrieving some information from Qt's GUI things, but I don't want to have a dependency for QtWidgets and QtDeclarative (because I only need these data to do some math calculations), so I'm using raw QObject pointers to retrieve these info through Qt's meta object system, something like obj->property("some property").toSomeType(), but QQuickItem's properties are not exactly the same with QWidget's properties, so I have to judge between them. And due to most Qt classes inherits from QObject, to make the code robust, I also have to judge whether the given QObject is inherited from QWidget/QQuickItem or not. We have isWindow/isWidget for this kind of scenarios so I wonder why we only lack the one for Qt Quick. I admit I can use obj->inherit("QQuickItem") to do the same thing, but it doesn't look very good if use this together with isWidget.

Yeah I thought so.  There is an alternative though, the same sort of duck-typing that you can do in JS: check for the specific properties that you want to access, and it may turn out that you don't need conditional logic using the class type itself.  Items have a few properties that widgets don't, and vice-versa; and subclasses have specific properties that the parents don't.

But this idea still seems ok anyway, it won't hurt to have it.

Patch Set 2:

I'm fine with this going in, also still in 6.3, but please update the corresponding change in qtdeclarative (https://codereview.qt-project.org/c/qt/qtdeclarative/+/385974) and get that one approved as well before staging this one, lest we end up with an API addition in QtCore that never returns what it should.

messages.message:
Patch Set 1: Sanity-Review-1

(2 comments)

See http://wiki.qt.io/Early_Warning_System for explanations.

Patch Set 2:

Any reason to put these in qt5 and not qtbase?

If they live in qt5, when you need to change something in the scripts in an incompatible way, qtdeclarative which might not have been adapted yet, will suddenly use the new qt5 scripts and fail.

If you put them into qtbase, you can use the scripts associated with the qtbase sha1 in qtdedclarative/dependencies.yaml.

This would basically be what we currently do with Coin CI instructions living in qtbase, rather than qt5.git

Patch Set 3:

Changed the scripts' license blurb to GPL3.

Patch Set 3:

> Patch Set 2:
> 
> Any reason to put these in qt5 and not qtbase?

qtbase is the only repo not using these scripts so far. Additionally, I would really like to avoid cloning qtbase from all submodules. It takes long, while cloning qt5 takes a couple of seconds.

> 
> If they live in qt5, when you need to change something in the scripts in an incompatible way, qtdeclarative which might not have been adapted yet, will suddenly use the new qt5 scripts and fail.
> 
> If you put them into qtbase, you can use the scripts associated with the qtbase sha1 in qtdedclarative/dependencies.yaml.
> 
> This would basically be what we currently do with Coin CI instructions living in qtbase, rather than qt5.git

As this is just informational for the time being I guess it's alright to fail a couple of builds. This is far from perfect so far, and will fail for other reasons too (like missing artifacts, races between building and uploading artifacts between submodules etc). I find the greatest virtue it has so far is simplicity and speed.

Patch Set 6: Sanity-Review-1

(2 comments)

See http://wiki.qt.io/Early_Warning_System for explanations.

Patch Set 6:

I have added here more functionality that is common to building all modules.

Do you think it would make sense to create a new repository for that? Maybe name it qt/common because it would contain common files used in different places?

Patch Set 7: Sanity-Review-1

(2 comments)

See http://wiki.qt.io/Early_Warning_System for explanations.

Patch Set 7:

(2 comments)

On another note, do we need the long copyright notice for small scripts or scripts with build instructions? I'd rather keep simple scripts fitting in one screen-full.

Patch Set 8: Sanity-Review-1

(3 comments)

See http://wiki.qt.io/Early_Warning_System for explanations.

Patch Set 9: Sanity-Review-1

(3 comments)

See http://wiki.qt.io/Early_Warning_System for explanations.
Uploaded patch set 10: Patch Set 9 was rebased.

Patch Set 10: Sanity-Review-1

(3 comments)

See http://wiki.qt.io/Early_Warning_System for explanations.

Patch Set 10:

Another effort to get this in. This will enable us to build submodules in Github Actions. I don't have much time to spend on this so I would appreciate to get this in so that Github Actions work in qtbase and submodules, and then improvements can come gradually as needed.

This creates the requirements to first clone qt5 repo, for all modules that build on Github Actions. To avoid cloning such a big repo on every module, I believe it would be better to have such scripts on a separate repo, for example "qtci". Let me know what you think.

Small followup fixes already follow this commit since the build requirements have changed all this time. I would like to keep them separate to keep the history.

Patch Set 10:

Regarding the sanity bot comments: for readability's sake, I would like to skip the copyright header on simple scripts with build instructions.

Patch Set 10:

For reference, here is how Github Actions in qtbase will look like after: 
https://codereview.qt-project.org/c/qt/qtbase/+/315253

Patch Set 10:

> Patch Set 10:
> 
> Regarding the sanity bot comments: for readability's sake, I would like to skip the copyright header on simple scripts with build instructions.

I think the setup.sh script is long enough to get a copyright header; the info.sh and install.sh are perhaps ok without.

Can we have those scripts under the coin subdirectory though? Even if they are not for coin, but for general ci pipelines, it would be nice to have all CI related stuff in one place (and perhaps at some point outside of qt5.git and in its own submodule).

Patch Set 10:

> Patch Set 10:
> 
> > Patch Set 10:
> > 
> > Regarding the sanity bot comments: for readability's sake, I would like to skip the copyright header on simple scripts with build instructions.
> 
> I think the setup.sh script is long enough to get a copyright header; the info.sh and install.sh are perhaps ok without.

Adding copyright header.

> 
> Can we have those scripts under the coin subdirectory though? Even if they are not for coin, but for general ci pipelines, 

The coin subdirectory has a README file that says "This directory contains files used by Qt's Continuous Integration system (Coin)". However these files here are completely independent from Coin.

(2 comments)

See http://wiki.qt.io/Early_Warning_System for explanations.

nice cleanup, probably adding some more typed objects could make some of the string operations cleaner.
Just toLiteral to fix..

Patch Set 4: Code-Review+2

With QAnyString things are indeed nice, sorry for the noise. I still think that string are a bit noisy, but it is generated code...

Patch Set 4:

> With QAnyString things are indeed nice, sorry for the noise. I still think that string are a bit noisy, but it is generated code...

Hmm, nothing to do with QAnyString. The QStringLiteral expands to roughly:
QString::fromRawData{ nullptr, u"" <your string in quotes>, sizeof(whatever you have passed) }

Same for QByteArrayLiteral but that one expands into an analogy of QByteArray::fromRawData().

subject: RFC: Make QRect::center() work as expected with empty rects

values.-1: I would prefer this is not merged as is
values.+1: Looks good to me, but someone else must approve

messages.message:
Patch Set 1:

Most likely, this is going to be a controversial change. In case changing QRect::center() is not an option, would it be okay if a new method to calculate center point is added? e.g.

```
QPoint QRect::centerR() const
{ return QPoint(left + (right - left) / 2, top + (bottom - top) / 2); }
```

Patch Set 1:

I don't see this flying, not because it doesn't make sense, but because any change there is going to break a lot of code. I'd rather indeed introduce another dedicated function, and enough docs to explain differences.

Patch Set 1:

in how far does this affect situations which are not corner cases for which no reasonable behavior could be expected in the first place so far?

Patch Set 1:

> Patch Set 1:
> 
> in how far does this affect situations which are not corner cases for which no reasonable behavior could be expected in the first place so far?

I'm not sure that I fully understand the question, but kwin uses the center of the window to determine what output it's on. The output is used to look up the work area, the maximize area and things as such.

For example, if there are two outputs - `QRect(0, 0, 1920, 1080)` and `QRect(1920, 0, 1920, 1080)`, and the window has `QRect(1920, 0, 0, 0)` geometry, `QRect::center()` will return `QPoint(1919, 0)`, which is on the first output and thus window can be placed on a wrong screen if it's maximized. A window can be empty during initialization, which is normal on Wayland.

Patch Set 1:

the question was (somewhat obviously) aimed at peppe's concerns regarding compatibility.

Patch Set 1:

> Patch Set 1:
> My concern is that people who fell into this trap and want some different semantics are already working around this trap *somehow*. QRect is absolutely central code, so central that ANY behavior change will break someone's code (Hyrum's law).

Yes, unfortunately, it may break code. However, I've been running plasma with this patch for a while now and it's been pretty smooth so far.

> Similarly: code doing center() must already be deploying their own workarounds, and so this change will break it.

I can add a second center() method, but it will be very confusing to have two center properties and it won't change the fact that there's already can be code broken because of QRect::center() not having the expected value after calling QRect::moveCenter().

Patch Set 1:

(2 comments)

Ok so the real issue here is that center() will truncate half coordinates towards zero, instead of consistently downwards. The result is that when a center coordinate is negative, and between ints, the result becomes one off compared to when it is positive, or compared to moveCenter(). This a real bug.

(The result on empty rects is just a side effect, and imho unimportant. It is not obvious that an empty rect has a center at all; it could even be argued that it should be null.)

So the compat question reduces to the question of a one off for rects with a) negative top and/or left AND b) even width and/or height. While b) is the common case, a) is definitely not...

messages.message:
Patch Set 1: Code-Review-1

If the new order catches latent bugs, why revert?

Patch Set 1:

Because, strictly speaking, they were not wrong. If the global static were, indeed, a global static, then recursing back into it while the destructor is running is fine. It's only after the destructor has finished (for each class, at least) where the problem starts.

And because of the potential to create runtime problems with existing applications. I don't think it's worth it.
Uploaded patch set 2: Commit message was updated.

Patch Set 2:

> Patch Set 1:
> 
> Because, strictly speaking, they were not wrong. If the global static were, indeed, a global static, then recursing back into it while the destructor is running is fine.
> It's only after the destructor has finished (for each class, at least) where the problem starts.

That's imprecise: It's fine only as long as the destructor _body_ executes. Once you start executing the member dtors, it's base-class-only, if any, so if we cast from `&storage` to T* in pointer(), that's UB.  

The only way to avoid the UB is to set the guard to Destroyed and _then_ destroy.
 
> And because of the potential to create runtime problems with existing applications. I don't think it's worth it.

Avoiding UB is always worth it, in my book. YMMV.

Patch Set 2:

> Patch Set 2:
> 
> > Patch Set 1:
> > 
> > Because, strictly speaking, they were not wrong. If the global static were, indeed, a global static, then recursing back into it while the destructor is running is fine.
> > It's only after the destructor has finished (for each class, at least) where the problem starts.
> 
> That's imprecise: It's fine only as long as the destructor _body_ executes. Once you start executing the member dtors, it's base-class-only, if any, so if we cast from `&storage` to T* in pointer(), that's UB.  
> 
> The only way to avoid the UB is to set the guard to Destroyed and _then_ destroy.
>  
> > And because of the potential to create runtime problems with existing applications. I don't think it's worth it.
> 
> Avoiding UB is always worth it, in my book. YMMV.

That is a good point I was about to write I also considered that accessing the memory during the destructor ok, but indeed during the destruction the class virtual table regresses to the super classes for example, and casting it back is a bad idea.

Patch Set 2:

> > That's imprecise: It's fine only as long as the destructor _body_ executes. Once you start executing the member dtors, it's base-class-only, if any, so if we cast from `&storage` to T* in pointer(), that's UB.  

Correct, but that's the case here.

> > The only way to avoid the UB is to set the guard to Destroyed and _then_ destroy.

If we want to avoid it altogether. But there are valid use-cases for reentering from inside the body of the destructor and those aren't UB.

> > > And because of the potential to create runtime problems with existing applications. I don't think it's worth it.
> > 
> > Avoiding UB is always worth it, in my book. YMMV.
> 
> That is a good point I was about to write I also considered that accessing the memory during the destructor ok, but indeed during the destruction the class virtual table regresses to the super classes for example, and casting it back is a bad idea.

We only have a very broad stroke. We can prevent all UB at the expense of disallowing some valid use-cases, or we can allow the valid use-cases and let people run into an UB in case they write wrong code. The previous implementation allowed the valid case and leaned on the developer in not running into UB.

Oh, a null-pointer dereference is UB.

Patch Set 2:

> Oh, a null-pointer dereference is UB.

Yes, but we can and do assert on it in debug mode.

The Other UB only shows up in ubsan, it cannot be asserted on.

If you want to revert for 6.3, because it's late, fine. But I'd really wish we kept this in dev. Then again, it will be a surprise for _someone_ even if we delayed it to Qt 7. The Law of Hyrum strong in this one is.

Patch Set 2:

Well a class destructor calling a subclass static global is definitely very convoluted, but calling itself not so much so I definitely see the "leave room for people to hang themselves" option as reasonable, as we had cases of this behaviour, and others will also be bitten by this change.
I understand Marc point, and the law of Hyrum note is not a good reason to change it, it means that we expose subtle bugs in others code.
So I am still undecided about the best option here

Patch Set 2:

Need more opinions here.

Patch Set 2: Code-Review-1

see my comments above for rationale

Patch Set 2:

Given that we had one instance of an issue in all of Qt so far, I'm not pushing for this patch, at least not until users start to loudly complain on the bug tracker.

However, if we don't change the order, we should IMHO at least adjust the documentation to explicitly warn about the behaviour during destruction. Currently, we only mention QCoreApplication. After all, with a real global static, accessing the object while its dtor hasn't completed would be fine.

subject: Rewrite Q_{GLOBAL,APPLICATION}_STATIC with C++17 goodies

values.-1: I would prefer this is not merged as is
values.+1: Looks good to me, but someone else must approve

messages.message:
Patch Set 1:

Looks good to me.
Everything still seems to be working as expected, at least everything I tested in our use case.

You probably need to have a look at the includes/usage in other modules, since the try to include 'QGlobalStatic' and fail, e.g.: qtdeclarative/src/quick/designer/qquickdesignercustomobjectdata.cpp:45:10: fatal error: 'QGlobalStatic' file not found

Also most of the documentation in qglobalstatic.qdoc now seems to be obsolete.

Patch Set 1:

> You probably need to have a look at the includes/usage in other modules, since the try to include 'QGlobalStatic' and fail, e.g.: qtdeclarative/src/quick/designer/qquickdesignercustomobjectdata.cpp:45:10: fatal error: 'QGlobalStatic' file not found

That can be fixed.

Patch Set 2:

(3 comments)

I'm left wondering why we don't make the plain versions of these macros varargs, now that we have the option.  We'd still need QGS_W_A() for backwards-compat, of course, but we could make it redundant.

Patch Set 5: Code-Review+2

I still don't think the atomics are correct, but it's not worse than it was before, so approving. It's quite a large change, so I didn't do a full review.

Patch Set 5:

Can you review the implementation detail docs and see if they make sense? I can wait a day... feature freeze is not until Friday.

Patch Set 8:

This breaks qtdeclarative's QQuickPixmapStore, whose dtor triggers a method which then tries to access the global static:
removeFromCache calls pixmapStore()->m_cache.remove(key);
where pixmapStore is the global static.

This leads to the following trace:
==25014==ERROR: AddressSanitizer: SEGV on unknown address 0x000000000010 (pc 0x7f8074f3cc69 bp 0x7ffeb09a3810 sp 0x7ffeb09a3800 T0)
==25014==The signal is caused by a READ memory access.
==25014==Hint: address points to the zero page.
    #0 0x7f8074f3cc69 in QHash<QQuickPixmapKey, QQuickPixmapData*>::isEmpty() const /home/fabian/projects/qtdev/qtbase/src/corelib/tools/qhash.h:860
    #1 0x7f8074f34f12 in QHash<QQuickPixmapKey, QQuickPixmapData*>::remove(QQuickPixmapKey const&) /home/fabian/projects/qtdev/qtbase/src/corelib/tools/qhash.h:889
    #2 0x7f8074f21c06 in QQuickPixmapData::removeFromCache() /home/fabian/projects/qtdev/qtdeclarative/src/quick/util/qquickpixmapcache.cpp:1329
    #3 0x7f8074f1ff2a in QQuickPixmapStore::shrinkCache(int) /home/fabian/projects/qtdev/qtdeclarative/src/quick/util/qquickpixmapcache.cpp:1189
    #4 0x7f8074f1f2e2 in QQuickPixmapStore::~QQuickPixmapStore() /home/fabian/projects/qtdev/qtdeclarative/src/quick/util/qquickpixmapcache.cpp:1118
    #5 0x7f8074f2ba59 in ~Holder /home/fabian/projects/qtdev/qtbase/src/corelib/global/qglobalstatic.h:79
    #6 0x7f806d9104a6 in __run_exit_handlers (/usr/lib/libc.so.6+0x3f4a6)
    #7 0x7f806d91064d in exit (/usr/lib/libc.so.6+0x3f64d)
    #8 0x7f806d8f8b2b in __libc_start_main (/usr/lib/libc.so.6+0x27b2b)
    #9 0x55d8057b250d in _start (/tmp/tmp.saGpf1qHbt/build_dir/tst_qquickpixmapcache+0x8250d)

Do we consider this to be a bug in Q_GLOBAL_STATIC, or is this QQPixmapStore abusing API?

Patch Set 8:

Right, so we need to set it to destroyed before destroying, so it won't recurse.

Patch Set 8:

Wait, we do that. So how did that ever work for the previous version?

Patch Set 8:

> Patch Set 8:
> 
> Wait, we do that. So how did that ever work for the previous version?

The guard was set to destroyed _after_ the dtor ran. First bug caught by doing it the other way around, I'd wager.

The crashing code needs a strategic

    if (!pixmapCache.exist()) return;

or

    if (pixmapCache.isDestroyed()) return;

Patch Set 8:

> Patch Set 8:
> 
> > Patch Set 8:
> > 
> > Wait, we do that. So how did that ever work for the previous version?
> 
> The guard was set to destroyed _after_ the dtor ran. First bug caught by doing it the other way around, I'd wager.

Hmm... right. It was set in HolderBase's destructor, which ran after the Holder::value member got destroyed.

We can do the same. I think we have to do the same to avoid compatibility issues, even though the new way sounds more correct.


> The crashing code needs a strategic
> 
>     if (!pixmapCache.exist()) return;
> 
> or
> 
>     if (pixmapCache.isDestroyed()) return;

Indeed.

Patch Set 8:

It seems this is causing regression in webengine, see https://codereview.qt-project.org/c/qt/qtwebengine/+/387019 & https://bugreports.qt.io/browse/QTBUG-99406

messages.message:
Patch Set 1:

Good addition to the api, I think, but why not just implement it with a call to rotate instead of repeating much of the logic?

Patch Set 1:

> Patch Set 1:
> 
> Good addition to the api, I think, but why not just implement it with a call to rotate instead of repeating much of the logic?

Because, as with the fromScale() and fromTranslate(), this is marginally faster, both functions do a similar thing for that reason. Otherwise yes I would have just wrapped around rotate() :)

Patch Set 1:

> Because, as with the fromScale() and fromTranslate(), this is marginally faster, both functions do a similar thing for that reason. Otherwise yes I would have just wrapped around rotate() :)

True, but those have trivial implementations...

subject: Say hello to the new Dependency Update Bot

values.-1: I would prefer this is not merged as is
values.+1: Looks good to me, but someone else must approve

messages.message:
Patch Set 1: Sanity-Review-1

(4 comments)

See http://wiki.qt.io/Early_Warning_System for explanations.

Patch Set 1:

this is just amazing. i say get rid of the yaml files, you just go ahead and try to entrench them even further. i say we have init-repository which already serves many of the purposes this is apparently aimed at, you create a new tool. and to make it even more fun, you optionally use git modules as well. somehow.

remove all the python meta gunk, update your gitignore, and ideally update the commit sanitizer to complain about .pyc and .lock files.

Patch Set 1:

> i say get rid of the yaml files, you just go ahead and try to entrench them even further.
No concrete proposals at the contributors summit were tabled. From the discussion was gathered one thing: "eh, I guess the submodules stay". Which frankly, is fine as far as I'm concerned, so I don't feel a conflict working on this.

> i say we have init-repository which already serves many of the purposes this is apparently aimed at, you create a new tool
This bot is a drop-in replacement for the existing bot with a bit more flexibility. Nothing more. I don't know what you're getting at here.

> and to make it even more fun, you optionally use git modules as well. somehow.
In order to "remove" a submodule from qt5.git, it needs to pass CI, which means that you need to touch .gitmodules where relevant during the final step of a submodule update round where you stripped the dependency from a module. That's all that does.
Uploaded patch set 3: Commit message was updated.

Patch Set 3: Code-Review-2 Sanity-Review+1

Apparently pushing a Work In Progress

Patch Set 2:

> No concrete proposals at the contributors summit were tabled.

that's because that wasn't necessary. this topic was discussed at least two times on the list, plus more on jira. if you actually cared you'd have done the research.

> I don't feel a conflict working on this.

you're creating (well, entrenching) a competing structure to git modules. that's an _inherent_ conflict.

> This bot is a drop-in replacement for the existing bot with a bit more flexibility. Nothing more.

of course it is more; it clearly has overlap with init-repository, which is a regular dev tool. also, if that wasn't so, this would have absolutely no place in this repo.

> In order to "remove" a submodule from qt5.git, it needs to pass CI, which means that you need to touch .gitmodules where relevant during the final step of a submodule update round where you stripped the dependency from a module. That's all that does.

iow, it supports a process that shouldn't exist in this form in the first place.

Uploaded patch set 8: Commit message was updated.

Patch Set 8: Code-Review-2

i expect answers.

Patch Set 8:

> Patch Set 8: Code-Review-2
> 
> i expect answers.

I gave you answers. If you so vehemently oppose rebuilding the current submodule update process to improve it, describe in no uncertain terms the exact methodology you would use avoid submodules and updating them to keep Qt in sync. I did keep up with the mailing list threads surrounding this, and I followed the session at the contributors summit. Again, no concrete or feasible alternatives were given, and "the init-repository script sort of kinda helps in some nebulous way" is unhelpful and unproductive.

Patch Set 8:

> I gave you answers.

no, you didn't. my previous message contains several concrete assertions that you didn't bother responding to in any way.

> Again, no concrete or feasible alternatives were given,

i made very clear what is wrong with the current solution and repeatedly gave directions where things could go to resolve the issues (specifically, my dialogs with vohi should be instructive). so far i haven't seen any evidence that what i've proposed is not feasible.

> "the init-repository script sort of kinda helps in some nebulous way" is unhelpful and unproductive.

there is nothing nebulous about it. if you don't understand how a specific requirement is (or could be) addressed by the infra surrounding gitmodules, ask in an appropriate forum. if you're serious about it, make a jira epic about replacing the yaml files and we'll work from there.

Patch Set 8:

> Patch Set 8:
> 
> > I gave you answers.
> 
> no, you didn't. my previous message contains several concrete assertions that you didn't bother responding to in any way.
> 
> > Again, no concrete or feasible alternatives were given,
> 
> i made very clear what is wrong with the current solution and repeatedly gave directions where things could go to resolve the issues (specifically, my dialogs with vohi should be instructive). so far i haven't seen any evidence that what i've proposed is not feasible.
> 
> > "the init-repository script sort of kinda helps in some nebulous way" is unhelpful and unproductive.
> 
> there is nothing nebulous about it. if you don't understand how a specific requirement is (or could be) addressed by the infra surrounding gitmodules, ask in an appropriate forum. if you're serious about it, make a jira epic about replacing the yaml files and we'll work from there.

Ossi, all the discussions on the mailing list fizzled out without any decision made by anyone, and, most importantly, without anyone sitting down and actually developing a single line of code that would have implemented an alternative solution. And I do not agree that those threads made a conversation at e.g. the contributors summit superfluous. Given that you are obviously passionate about the topic, I would have expected more proactiveness on this topic from you at the Qt CS or following up the email discussion, and at least an attempt to convince more people about your proposal. You chose not to do so. Giving instructions and directions and telling people how they should do stuff - that's quite frankly not the kind of contribution we are interested in.

The submodule update bot as it is, just as - but to a lesser degree than - the .gitmodules based workflow before, comes with significant operational cost, requiring too much handholding of the process. This rewrite is a valid attempt to reduce that operational cost, and provides us with a bit of automation that is based on our daily experience, esp in those modules where changes require touching multiple repositories. The people that work with these complexities every day have asked for these improvements, and while we are waiting for you to make a specific proposal, preferably in form of an implementation that can be reviewed here, I see no reason why we should not take small steps to improve the status quo without the current way of working.

Patch Set 8:

> I would have expected more proactiveness on this topic from you at the Qt CS or following up the email discussion, and at least an attempt to convince more people about your proposal.

i'm not sure what exactly you expect me to do. i don't have the nerve for this people shit, esp. in the context of tqtc management's cheapness and faux openness.

> I see no reason why we should not take small steps to improve the status quo without the current way of working.

yeah, whatever. as the de-facto maintainer of this repository i still expect specific responses to my specific questions/assertions. QTQAINFRA-1958 is an ongoing task.

Patch Set 8:

> Patch Set 8:
> 
> > I would have expected more proactiveness on this topic from you at the Qt CS or following up the email discussion, and at least an attempt to convince more people about your proposal.
> 
> i'm not sure what exactly you expect me to do. i don't have the nerve for this people shit, esp. in the context of tqtc management's cheapness and faux openness.
> 
> > I see no reason why we should not take small steps to improve the status quo without the current way of working.
> 
> yeah, whatever. as the de-facto maintainer of this repository i still expect specific responses to my specific questions/assertions. QTQAINFRA-1958 is an ongoing task.

"ongoing task"? The jira status is closed, and the task specifically pertains to the placement of different utilities, not the gitmodules vs. yaml dependencies debate.

Patch Set 8:

> "ongoing task"? The jira status is closed,

and it would be re-opened as soon as somebody screws it up again. so it's ongoing.

> and the task specifically pertains to the placement of different utilities, not the gitmodules vs. yaml dependencies debate.

correct. now read my comments again.

Patch Set 8:

> Patch Set 8:
> 
> > "ongoing task"? The jira status is closed,
> 
> and it would be re-opened as soon as somebody screws it up again. so it's ongoing.

What? You can't claim a closed Jira is an ongoing task because somebody might "screw it up again"(what does that even mean?)

> > and the task specifically pertains to the placement of different utilities, not the gitmodules vs. yaml dependencies debate.
> 
> correct. now read my comments again.

Again: What? I read through all the comments on the Jira and none of them touch on the gitmodules/dependencies debate.

Are you implying that the Jira somehow implicitly involves the debate at hand? Am I missing something?

Patch Set 8:

> You can't claim a closed Jira is an ongoing task because somebody might "screw it up again"

it's an ongoing maintenance effort. and if resolving that jira issue didn't result in some policy being written down and popularized, it *will* be botched up again. as i suspect you might be doing with this submission.

> I read through all the comments on the Jira and none of them touch on the gitmodules/dependencies debate.

the comments *here*. the jira task is context. which you should understand after re-reading the comments.
